conclusion: To determine the minimum safe distance between the motorcycle and the car to prevent a collision, we need to analyze the motion of both vehicles after they start braking.
We'll use the given velocity-time graph for the motorcycle and the velocity-time relationship for the car.
From the graph, the initial velocity of the motorcycle is \( v_{1i} = 4 \, \text{m/s} \).
The final velocity of the motorcycle is \( v_{1f} = 0 \, \text{m/s} \).
The time taken to stop is \( t = 8 \, \text{s} \).

premise: Initial velocity \( v_{1i} = 4 \, \text{m/s} \), final velocity \( v_{1f} = 0 \, \text{m/s} \), time \( t = 8 \, \text{s} \).
conclusion: The deceleration \( a_1 \) of the motorcycle is \( a_1 = \frac{v_{1f} - v_{1i}}{t} = \frac{0 - 4}{8} = -0.5 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
The velocity of the car as a function of time is given by \( v_2 = 3 - 0.25t \).
The initial velocity of the car is \( v_{2i} = 3 \, \text{m/s} \).
The deceleration \( a_2 \) of the car is \( a_2 = -0.25 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).

premise: Initial velocity \( v_{1i} = 4 \, \text{m/s} \), deceleration \( a_1 = -0.5 \, \text{m/s}^2 \), time \( t = 8 \, \text{s} \).
conclusion: The distance \( d_1 \) traveled by the motorcycle is \( d_1 = v_{1i} t + \frac{1}{2} a_1 t^2 = 32 - 16 = 16 \, \text{m} \).
The car stops when its velocity \( v_2 \) becomes zero, \( t = \frac{3}{0.25} = 12 \, \text{s} \).
